Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The project is still in exploratory discussions, and alternative approaches can be proposed later
Story: My phone buzzed at 2 a.m., jolting me awake. It was Sam, my closest friend, his voice trembling as he told me about his father’s sudden illness. He needed me—someone to listen, to help him make sense of the chaos. I sat up, heart pounding, trying to focus on his words, to be present for him. But in the back of my mind, the project I’d been mulling over all week crept in. We were still in the early stages, but I’d promised myself I’d sketch out some ideas tonight, before the team meeting tomorrow. I could almost see the blank page on my desk, the pressure to contribute something innovative, to prove my worth as an engineer. Sam’s sobs pulled me back. He was counting on me, but so was my team. I felt torn, guilt gnawing at me—how could I be a good friend and a responsible engineer at the same time? My mind raced, caught between the urge to comfort Sam and the responsibility to my work, unsure which part of me should take the lead.
